title: springhead primary school anlaby hull name parents afford school dinners
story: On a feeling hopeful Facebook post, Springhead Primary School in Hull announced they would have a zero tolerance regime for those unable to cough up for school lunches.The Hull primary school said there were 60 parents in debt - and threatened to withdraw their childrens lunch or after school/breakfast club for the first half of the autumn term if they did not settle their account by tomorrow.The controversial post added: Many parents have paid upfront and are in credit.Thank you to those who have done so. (Please dont make us name and shame you).The post finishes with the hashtags: wedidntsignuptobedebtcollectors #pleasedontmakeusnag #cantpaythestaff.Parents were divided over the warning, which gave them just two days notice to pay their dues.Emma Hall wrote: I think this is absolutely disgusting!I understand the school needs to chase the money they are owed but these families could be genuinely struggling.She added: If they name and shame all they are going to do is fuel bullying between the children and make the parents feel worse than they probably already do!Kamel Fanee Rokyckyj added: The comment of name and shame is disgusting that would just cause bullying for the children when none of this is their fault at all!I understand the school needs to get the money but taking a child’s meal away or naming parents children is wrong!However a number of parents appeared to side with the school, with Sarah Todd arguing: School shouldnt have to feed your child for free.If they aren’t entitled they must be able to afford dinner or do a packup, she said.School shouldn’t have to feed your child for free. I bet after Friday they get paid or the children go back in Sept with a pack up.She added: I wouldn’t go to Mcdonalds ask for a Happy Meal and walk away without paying because it for my child.Others, including Allen Preen, suggested a middle ground.He said: Kids school meals are like any other debt that has to be budgeted for. How about a policy whereby the meals have to be paid upfront.The message has now been deleted since it was first posted on Wednesday.Springhead Primary School refused to comment when contacted by The Sun Online.

title: kennet and avon canal dried out doors left open
story: A stretch of the Kennet and Avon Canal was left with just a trickle of water running through it and boats left resting on the mud.A spokesperson for the Canal and River Trust confirmed to the BBC a boater was rushing and left the paddles up.He explained the paddles work like a plug on a bath in allowing water in and out of the locks - meaning hundreds of litres of water drained away.But the water levels have now been returned to normal, with the trust adding the mishap wasnt malicious.The spokesman said: We became aware first thing [Wednesday] morning and our team set to work to restore the water levels.As only one stretch of canal was affected the water levels have now all returned back to normal within a few hours.“There wasn’t really any impact to boaters or wildlife that we are aware of.“We managed to fill the canal up fairly quickly and the fish either swam further down the canal with the flow of water or remained in the little pool of water left behind.”The Kennet and Avon Canal stretches for 87 miles and links the River Thames at Reading to the River Avon in Bath.It was originally opened in 1810 but fell into decline before the turst and volunteers restored it in August 1990.

title: girl chemical burns homemade slim google recipe
story: Layla Fisher, ten, burned her skin leaving nasty blisters from the recipe she found online.She mixed together common ingredients used to make the toy goo, including PVA glue, shaving foam and contact lens solution, which contains the powerful chemical borax.Horrified mum, Gemma Williams, 39, believes it was the borax, also found in household cleaning products, that left her daughter covered in painful blisters.The mum-of-two is sharing photos of Laylas burns to warn other parents of the dangers the playground craze.Gemma, from Oadby, Leics. said: We were shocked when she got these terrible finger burns.The doctor said they were chemical burns from the slime she made herself.“They were really sore looking and it gradually got worse as the day wore on.Layla was at home making a batch of slime earlier this month, something she did regularly.Using ingredients from her parents kitchen and bathroom cupboards, as well as some food colouring and glitter, she played with the toy for a couple of hours.That evening she complained of having itchy fingers.But the next morning, Layla woke up and her fingers were covered in blisters, which got worse over the weekend.With the GP surgery closed, mum Gemma said she hoped the irritation would calm down and waited until Monday to book a doctors appointment.The GP diagnosed Layla with chemical burns, and told her mum the slime was the culprit.It was bad enough but it could have been a lot worse, Gemma warned.With chemicals like this involved its not only skin problems you need to consider, the worry is the fumes as well.It could have been fatal.Layla had been making her own slime for several weeks, creating at least 30 batches of the popular toy.We dont know what went wrong with this batch, it was obviously the wrong concoction, Gemma said.Its a real craze with kids that age.They play about with it, stick their fingers in it, pull it around and then put it in a container.Parents are even hosting slime parties where they make the stuff - thats how popular its become.Gemma said she believes the contact lens solution seems to be the problem, as it contains borax.Earlier this week a Which? investigation found eight out of 11 slime toys tested contained potentially dangerous levels of borax.The chemical is linked to diarrhoea, stomach cramps, and is feared to cause health problems in unborn babies as well as infertility problems.Laylas GP prescribed an antibacterial cream and told Gemma to seek further help if the blisters didnt clear up in a couple of days.The following Thursday, she took Layla to Leicester Royals A&ampE department, where doctors revealed the burns had developed into the skin infection, impetigo.She had open sores on her hands and the skin was just peeling off her fingers, it was awful, Gemma said.A small patch had spread to her face and arm, it was then we were told she had impetigo.The A&ampE doctor was surprised when he heard it was caused by playing with slime.Layla is still taking antibiotics, but the blisters and infection has almost cleared up completely, two weeks later.Gemma said as a parent she felt guilty, and questioned whether she should have been monitoring her daughter more closely.One things for certain, she wont be touching that stuff again, the 39-year-old added.Layla said despite loving playing with slime with her friends, she be doing so in future.I started playing with slime as all my friends were and I just wanted to join in, the primary school pupil said.I thought it was really cool.The last time I played with it I just googled the recipe, the slime felt a bit fluffier than usual, but it was fine.“When I woke up the next morning they were still itchy and when I looked down my fingers were blistered, it was then I thought ‘I need to tell my mum’.“It all got worse and started spreading to my fingers on both hands. When the doctor felt them it really hurt.“I also felt embarrassed because they just looked horrible. I don’t want it to happen to anyone again, it’s toxic stuff.”

title: new york explosion broadway smoke 5th avenue
story: Local reports suggest a steam pipe has exploded near the iconic Flatiron Building at the corner of 5th Avenue and 21st street.Twitter user Casie Jordan posted a video of the incident which showed a thick tower of smoke shooting out of the road.She wrote: Some kind of explosion on Broadway and 21st.NBC New York reports that the explosion was reported shortly after 6:40am in the Big Apple just as rush hour was about to kick in.No one has been injured by the blast but traffic has been shut down between 20th and 23rd Street.WABC reported there also were manhole explosions from West 19th Street to West 21st streets. Some subway trains were bypassing the area.I looked around and saw this big huge plume of steam shoot into the air, said Daniel Lizio-Katzen, 42, who was riding his bike home to the West Village.It was a pretty violent explosion, Lizio-Katzen told the Daily News.The steam was shooting up into the air about 70 feet. It was pushing up at such a high pressure that it was spewing all of this dirt and debris.The cars around were coated in mud ... It left a huge crater in the middle of the street.Brendan Walsh, 22, a senior at New York University, had just gotten off a train and was headed to class when he saw the plume.The billows were about six stories high. There was a large scatter of debris, he said. I was standing behind the police line when a Con Cd worker came rushing over and screaming at police and firefighters to push everyone north because he was worried that there could be secondary manhole explosions.Everyone including the police and firefighters who were standing by started moving back, he said.Buildings along several blocks of Fifth Avenue have been evacuated as a precaution.An FDNY spokesman described it as a high pressure steam leak but said investigators are yet to conclusively say what caused it.In a spooky turn of events the blast comes almost exactly 11 years after another steam pipe burst in the city.That explosion killed one person and injured 45 after a pipe ruptured on the corner of 41st Street and Lexington Avenue on July 18 2007.

title: emelia holden waitress grabbed vinnie van go go savannah georgia
story: CCTV footage shows Emelia Holden, 21, sorting through a pile of menus at Vinnie Van Go-Gos in Savannah, Georgia, when the perv gropes her on his way out.But brave Emelia immediately turned to grab him by the scruff of his neck - before throwing him against a wall with one arm.She then berates him in front of other customers before telling co-workers to call the police.The customer was hauled off in cuffs after cops reviewed CCTV footage.Emelia said: I just did what I felt was best. I took the guy down and had my co-workers call the police.As soon as the cops saw the CCTV footage, they immediately arrested the man. He sat in jail until Monday so in my opinion, he got what he deserved.All that I want from my experiences is for women to know that its okay to stand up for yourself.You have every right to wear what you want and you most certainly have every right to defend yourself.

title: bitter ferocious debate who gets to be a woman
story: Initially, no one on either side was prepared to speak to us - scared of repercussions and reticent about being misrepresented in such a polarised debate.Many transgender people refused to go on record alongside the feminist campaigners who they say deny their very existence.Jess Bradley, the transgender officer for the National Union of Students, identifies as a non-binary woman and was one of the few trans women prepared to speak on camera.She said her community feels under siege and is subject to abuse, which she says has risen sharply since the debate started."It's a hostile time, trans people are very scared... I know simply by doing this piece of media, I will be hounded on social media, it will have a real material impact on my life," she said."One of the things about the gender recognition debate is it's given licence to anti-trans activists using this is an excuse to debate our existence&#8230 in a way that has felt very violent."It feels extremely painful to have a group of people campaigning against your participation in everyday life.":: Opinion - "We need to combat moral hysteria over gender recognition"   She is talking about the so called gender critical feminists. This is a group of women who are worried that the right to self-identify - essentially ticking a box to become a woman as they see it - is open to abuse, compromising female-only spaces and eroding women's rights.We were shocked at the vitriol expressed online from both sides of this conflict.Dr Nicola Williams is another staunch feminist embroiled in the debate. She warns that a system which allows anyone to self-certify as women would be open to abuse, and that it would amount to an attack on women's rights.But all the trans men and women we spoke to were at pains to stress that for them, there is nothing theoretical about this issue.Far from theory, this is their reality. The misunderstanding and misinformation surrounding the GRA and self-identification makes everyday life even harder for a group of people already subject to prejudice and abuse.They point out that the Equalities Act is the law that allows trans people to use the facilities appropriate to their preferred gender.So for many years trans people have been using changing rooms, toilets and women's services such as rape centres - and there is no evidence to suggest that there has been any problem with this at all.The British Social Attitudes Survey, an annual study of public beliefs carried out by NatCen, gave this year's findings on attitudes to transgender people exclusively to Sky News.In general, the public seem to be liberal with 84% claiming not to be prejudiced at all against trans people.

title: comcast drops fox bid to focus on sky takeover
story: Shares of 21st Century Fox have fallen by 1.5% in pre-market trading.Comcast's decision to walk away from the battle for Fox's assets could mean an intensification of the battle to take control of Sky.Fox, which is currently Sky's biggest shareholder with a 39.1% stake, sought to take full control of the company in December 2016 with an offer valuing the company at &#16318.5bn.That bid was snared up in regulatory investigations - leaving Comcast free to swoop in February with a &#16322.1bn offer of its own.

title: eu member states told to step up no deal brexit preparations
story: It added "there is still no certainty that there will be a ratified withdrawal agreement in place on that date [30 March 2019]".The release of the commission's document came as Dominic Raab made his first visit to Brussels as the new Brexit secretary for talks with Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator.The 16-page leaflet also warns::: A "no deal" Brexit could result in "significant delays" to transport and a "significant drawback" for trade:: UK individuals and organisations could become ineligible for EU grants and unable to bid for EU contracts:: Products could require new authorisations and certifications:: Professionals may need to have their qualifications recognised by an EU member state as well as the UKThe commission insisted its advice was not "a sign of mistrust in the negotiations".If the talks proceed according to plan, a withdrawal agreement and a political declaration on future relations will be agreed by October. This will allow enough time for the exit deal to be ratified by the British and European parliaments.On the prospect of Britain exiting the EU without a deal, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said the progress made so far suggests "that is not where we will end up".But he then warned: "We have to prepare in the event that there are either spiteful or ignorant or whatever activities by third parties."That obviously makes it very uncomfortable and some horrendous consequences, and that's what we have got to try and do our best to mitigate against."Fielding questions in the Commons before setting off to Brussels, Mr Raab said he was "relentlessly and unflinchingly" focused on getting a "win-win deal good for this country and good for our European friends".Mrs May, meanwhile, is making her first visit to the Irish border - a major sticking point in the negotiations - since the 2016 referendum vote. The threat to Mrs May's premiership sparked by disquiet over her Brexit blueprint appears to be subsiding as MPs prepared to head off on their summer breaks.But in an indication of the unease that remains within her party, Conservative Philip Davies has submitted a letter of no confidence in the PM's leadership.

title: jimmy mizens parents we made a promise to remain positive
story: For instance, being woken by Jimmy noisily crashing through the front door after a night out! Or see him, anxiety-ridden with the workload from his apprenticeship!What monsters we are to long to see him sick with worry about the first day of a new job! And isn't it cruel to wish to see him suffer with a hangover!We were determined that grief would not overwhelm. We made a promise to Jimmy to remain positive, to stay optimistic, to believe in hope.We mourn and we are sad, because we are human, but together we celebrate what Jimmy's life now means to so many more people than he could have possibly imagined.When we walked out of the courtroom on the last day of the trial for Jimmy's murder, we asked God for the strength to work in his name. We made a promise to each other not to go down the road of anger and bitterness.Instead, our choice was to stop this happening to others and turn tragedy into something positive.The For Jimmy charity believes in the value of young people's knowledge, of listening to their experiences and learning from their first-hand evidence.Our faith has sustained us through difficult times. We aim to be leading examples of what it means to be resilient, hard-working and committed.Just as our faith tells us we must spread the Christian message, For Jimmy has spread our message that we must show compassion, and that we must love one another.We have taken seriously the church's teachings on the importance of forgiveness and want to show the world that love and forgiveness are the ways to approach the problems in our society.

title: weather set to get hotter over weekend with highs of 30c
story: On Wednesday, Met Office forecasters announced this summer "could well be record-breaking" for the UK if the rest of the season remains above average.The highest temperature recorded in the UK this year was in Porthmadog in Wales, which reached 33C (91.4F) on 28 June.It could also be one of the five sunniest summers on record if the UK sees an average amount of sunshine through August.The prolonged rain in the North West will move further south overnight, affecting Wales and Central and southwest England on Friday.A Met Office yellow thunderstorm warning is in place for the South East between 2pm and 11.59pm on Friday, as the increasing heat and humidity could trigger some lively storms.

title: worlds first artificial meteor shower to light sky over japan in 2020
story: The plan is to have them orbiting the planet by February 2020, with a view to delivering a meteor shower over Hiroshima in spring the same year.If the skies are clear the display could be visible to millions of people over an area spanning 124 miles, ALE said."We are targeting the whole world, as our stockpile of shooting stars will be in space and can be delivered across the world," ALE chief executive Lena Okajima told a news conference.

title: grenfell emergency call operator relives
story: NewsGrenfell 999 operator relives comforting trapped girl, 12, until she 'heard her last gasps'Sarah Russell stayed on the phone for almost an hour to Jessica Urbano Ramirez, who called 999 complaining she could not escape due to the smoke.&nbspShareByMirror10:44, 19 JUL 2018Updated11:15, 19 JUL 2018NewsGrenfell Tower smoulders after an inferno ripped it apart (Image: PA)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA phone operator has described feeling completely helpless as she tried to comfort a trapped 12-year-old girl who died in the Grenfell Tower fire. Sarah Russell stayed on the phone for almost an hour to Jessica Urbano Ramirez, who called 999 complaining she could not escape due to the smoke. The girl told her she lived on the 20th floor but had taken refuge along with others higher up the tower block. Ms Russell said she answered the call, her first, at around 1.15am, and tried to get basic information from the little girl. In a written statement to the public inquiry, the London Fire Brigade control room officer said: I asked the girl what her name was and she told me it was Jessica.   'Whole community' raped girl, 12, for SEVEN MONTHS in latest horror attack in India  I asked Jessica if she was calling from her phone and I think she said she was. I asked to speak to someone a bit older to try and get some more information from them, but she did not hand it over I do not know why. Perhaps she did not want to. I felt I needed stay with her and that she needed me. I asked her if she wanted me to stay and she said 'yes'. I am glad I did - even if it was only to offer her a little support. The fact that she did not hand the phone to anyone else showed to me that she needed it. Ms Russell advised the very scared 12-year-old to go to the room least affected by smoke, shut the windows, stay low and cover her mouth. She went on: After about an hour I could not get anymore response from her - only rasping sounds, then nothing. I stayed on the line a little while longer with my hand hovered over the call termination button. I was torn as what best to do. I eventually ended the call when the line fell silent. Reflecting on that call, I felt completely helpless.  Met Police reveal Grenfell Tower fire MANSLAUGHTER prosecutions may be just around the corner    Grenfell campaigners stage dramatic walkout from Commons inquiry after accusing minister of lying  When people are pleading with you, saying do not want to die and I cannot physically do anything to help them it is very hard. I can pass on all the information but I cannot actually do anything - that is very tough. The information that Jessica had fled to a higher floor was not passed on to fire crews on the ground, who searched her flat but found no trace of the youngster. She was one of 72 people who died following the blaze on June 14 last year. Ms Russell revealed that, not long after the call ended, she became aware that the advice to callers had been changed from stay-put to attempt to evacuate. She said she did not recall ringing previous callers back with the changed advice, just answering the relentless calls and updating new callers. There was a lull in the calls at around 5am, Ms Russell said, recalling the words of a fellow operator. She said: It went eerily quiet and a little creepy. I remember someone saying, 'I wish they'd call again'. That way we would have known that they were still alive.

title: blow theresa cabinet minister esther
story: NewsBlow for Theresa May as Cabinet minister Esther McVey fails to fully back her Brexit planIt came hours after the Cabinet minister's partner, backbench Tory MP Philip Davies, handed in a letter of no confidence in the Prime Minister&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter14:21, 19 JUL 2018Updated14:30, 19 JUL 2018NewsCabinet minister Esther McVey avoided giving explicit backing to the plan, and her partner, Tory MP Philip Davies, today handed in a letter of no confidence in the Prime Minister (Image: DAILY MIRROR)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May suffered a new blow today as a Cabinet minister failed to give full-throated backing to her Brexit plan. Esther McVey was asked if she had full confidence in the Prime Minister’s 'soft Brexit' scheme drawn up at Chequers. But she replied with no reference to the plan, instead saying: I have full confidence in the Prime Minister to deliver the Brexit that Britain voted for.” It came hours after Tory MP Philip Davies handed in a letter of no confidence in the Prime Minister. The pair have long been close, arriving at a Tory fundraiser in February arm-in-arm and leaving hand-in-hand. In March Ms McVey was quoted in the Daily Mail saying: We're partners but we haven't done any official commitment stuff... yet.  Right-wing Brexiteer Mr Davies revealed his letter this morning saying he had lost trust in Theresa May's ability to deliver Brexit. The letter to voters in his Shipley constituency, obtained by the Yorkshire Post, said Mrs May's Chequers' plan for Brexit was unacceptable. It added: Politics is all about trust and once it is lost it is impossible to win back. Many people have told me that as a result of this they have lost trust in the PM to properly and fully deliver the referendum result. It is with much sadness that I have to say that I have also lost trust in her to deliver the referendum result too. Mr Davies said that Tories faced losing power to Jeremy Corbyn's Labour if they failed to deliver the Brexit which the country voted for in the 2016 EU referendum .  Failure to keep our promise to the electorate will almost certainly lead to the catastrophe of Jeremy Corbyn becoming prime minister and I cannot sit back and allow that to happen, he wrote. This has not been an easy decision and I have agonised over it, but I know in my heart of hearts it is the right decision. If 48 Tory MPs hand in no confidence letters it will trigger a full Conservative leadership contest. It is not known how many have been handed in and Mr Davies is only the third to go public, after Andrew Bridgen and Andrea Jenkyns.  Mr Davies' move comes hours after fellow Brexiteer Simon Clarke revealed he had withdrawn his own letter at a packed meeting of the backbench 1922 Committee. Mr Clarke told journalists afterwards: We’ve looked into the abyss in the last few days.” He said he was deeply opposed to her Chequers deal, but had withdrawn his letter because of “the threat from a Corbyn government or no Brexit at all. Theresa May agreed a major shift to soft Brexit at her country retreat Chequers - prompting her Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson to quit. The 'third way' plan for UK customs rules proposed keeping the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods. This will include sharing a common rulebook for all goods including agricultural and food products - and a possible compromise on migration. To appease Brexiteers, Parliament would keep the right to block future changes to the trading rules. But Brexiteers were enraged by this close link with Brussels and David Davis said this olive branch was meaningless in practice. The deal also proposes a common rulebook with the EU on state aid rules, and agrees to step up backup plans for a No Deal Brexit. A full White Paper was due to be published on Thursday 12 July.

title: tory esther mcvey denies universal
story: NewsTory Esther McVey DENIES Universal Credit has been too brutal - despite revealing yet more climbdowns to comeThe Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is "working on" changes that are "still needed" to the six-in-one welfare system - five years after it launched&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter13:52, 19 JUL 2018Updated14:28, 19 JUL 2018NewsThe Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is working on changes that are still needed to the six-in-one welfare system - five years after it launched (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory welfare chief Esther McVey today flatly denied Universal Credit has been too brutal - despite unveiling yet more climbdowns over the flagship benefit. The Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is working on changes that are still needed to the six-in-one welfare system - five years and a million claimants after it launched. They include more support for the self-employed and possible changes to the taper rate to let people keep more of the money they earn. But she refused to say the system had been flawed - or if she backs ex-welfare chief Iain Duncan Smith's call to pump in &pound2billion a year more. Mr Duncan Smith made his call after money was sucked out of the system before it launched in a move that will leave hundreds of thousands of families worse off. Asked by the Mirror if her climbdowns showed the system as rolled out was too harsh or brutal, she said: It was very very slow as we rolled it out so we were monitoring as we were rolled it out. So no, it wasn't, and we've stopped and changed it as we went along.  What is right is we continue to learn and change. Some &pound1.5billion was put into Universal Credit to make it fairer at last year's Budget, and further cash will be approved for people with severe disabilities. But in May Iain Duncan Smith, who held the job for six years before quitting over one benefit cut too far, called for &pound2billion more a year for UC on top of that. Ms McVey avoided saying whether she backed Mr Duncan Smith. Instead she pointed out the cash that had already been put in. In a speech to charities and campaigners at the Reform think tank, Ms McVey pleaded for their ideas to improve the benefit - despite it being in its sixth year. UC's rollout was blasted by the National Audit Office, pitching her into a public row with the watchdog when she was accused of misrepresenting its findings.  But Ms McVey said: We need to reach out to, learn from organisations such as yourselves, and yes, that includes the National Audit Office, about how to design and implement Universal Credit to support claimants. We want to work with you to understand where we can improve on this important reform. And there are changes that are still needed which I'm working on. Debt repayments, support for the self-employed, payment cycles for those in work, and an extension of outreach work and an extension of flexible support for claimants. Campaigners have warned self-employed workers face being crushed by UC because they are barred from claiming any more benefits than if they earned minimum wage. Ms McVey also signalled she could cut the 'taper rate', the amount of benefit taken away for every pound earned, further after it reduced from 65p to 63p. She said: If we can, yes we would look to reduce that.

title: exmoor beast giant cat size
story: News'Exmoor Beast' giant cat the size of LABRADOR dog with two foot-long tail jumps out in front of driverDavid Gliddon, 72, from Williton in Somerset, said the big feline creature leapt onto a wall in front of him while he was driving between Trentishoe and Heddon's Mouth in Devon&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJoel Cooper13:17, 19 JUL 2018Updated13:19, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man has described the jaw-dropping moment a giant cat jumped out in front of him while driving his car on a road in Devon. In jaw-dropping scenes, David Gliddon, 72, said the big feline creature leapt onto a wall in front of him while he was driving between Trentishoe and Heddon's Mouth on Exmoor. While he failed to take a photo, the sighting comes amid reports of others claiming they have seen evidence of the so called 'Exmoor Beast'.  David, from Williton in Somerset, described the cat as a great big thing with a thick, two foot long tail - and told DevonLive that the experience had left him dumbstruck.  He had been walking near Hunter's Inn on July 4 with his daughter prior to the sighting. It was the size of a large Labrador, or possibly bigger, he said.  It jumped up onto a wall about five yards in front of me on the road, the way it moved was just like a cat. Its tail was about two foot long and very thick, a constant width from start to finish. It was a browny greyish colour with slightly lighter, almost green flecks or spots. It was only there for an instant before it jumped over the other side of the wall. Stunned, David stopped the car in the middle of the road and ran to the wall to see if the animal was still there. He said: When I looked over the wall it looked like it had run off into the thick bracken.  I have never seen anything like this before. It was so clear. I was dumbstruck, I could not believe what I had seen. David, a keen wildlife watcher, says he is aware of wild mink and terrapins in this area, and the pythons and wallaby have also been spotted previously in West Somerset. He said: I've always kept an open mind. I've been on safari in Africa and seen a leopard from a distance, and this animal very similar in its characteristics. It was a jaw-dropping experience. I'd like to know if any farmers in that area have lost any sheep recently or if anyone else has spotted anything similar.

title: familys holiday nightmare passengers fainted
story: NewsFamily's holiday nightmare as 'passengers fainted and had panic attacks' on sweltering Thomas Cook plane stuck on tarmac for HOURSBekki Reece says conditions became so bad her 12-year-old daughter suffered a nose bleed, while her one-year-old girl was fanned by other travellers as temperatures soared&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMatt Jackson06:50, 19 JUL 2018Updated09:03, 19 JUL 2018NewsBekki Reece and partner Shane Davies were travelling back from Lanzarote (Image: Stoke Sentinel WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A family says their dream holiday turned into a nightmare as passengers fainted and had panic attacks on a sweltering Thomas Cook plane which was stuck on the tarmac for three hours waiting for take off.  Bekki Reece says conditions became so bad her 12-year-old daughter suffered a nose bleed, while her one-year-old girl was fanned by other travellers as temperatures soared to about 37C. The 32-year-old, from Biddulph, Staffordshire, says there was no air-con or water available as the plane sat waiting. Bekki, partner Shane Davies and her three young children were among 300 passengers trapped on the packed jet at Lanzarote airport.  She told the Stoke Sentinel conditions caused some to faint, suffer panic attacks and vomit as the smell of aviation fuel filled the cabin.   The family had been due to fly back with Thomas Cook to Manchester at 8.20pm on Thursday, July 5 but arrived at the airport only to be told they faced a two-and-a-half hour delay because of technical issues.   Bekki, who was also joined on the flight by mum Deb Dale and step-dad Michael Dale, said: “We got to the check-in and were told it would be a two-and-a-half hour delay but then at the gate it said three. We eventually boarded the plane but when we got on it was stifling - Shane said he felt sick. “After two hours my eldest daughter was having nose bleeds and my youngest looked as though she had just got out the bath because she was dripping with sweat. Passengers were using their safety cards to fan her down. It was really scary. She was so floppy and struggling to keep awake. “They opened the doors but there was a lot of commotion and after about three hours a young girl fainted. “I was worried for all our health - it was unbearable. Any longer and we would have all passed out.” Bekki, who also has a nine-year-old daughter, added: “Eventually the plane was taken back to the runway at 12.15am but we were told that under Lanzarote laws planes can’t take off after midnight.”

title: girl 7 sees parents as
story: NewsBrave little girl who sees her parents as Harry Potter DEMENTORS after brain tumour ravaged her sightEXCLUSIVE: Brave Eleanor Stollery was plunged into a world of dark shapes and shadows after she was diagnosed with a Hypothalamic Low-Grade Glioma age four&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings09:23, 19 JUL 2018Updated09:44, 19 JUL 2018NewsEleanor Stollery sees her parents Tim and Kelly in a very unique way (Image: timelesspictures)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA seven-year-old girl whose sight has been ravaged by an inoperable brain tumour now sees her parents as Dementors from Harry Potter. To Eleanor Stollery, her mum and dad, Kelly and Tim, look like something out of a horror film with black holes for eyes and slits for mouths. Their bodies appear like moving shadows and having lost her sight so young, she sadly no longer remembers their features. But despite being plunged into a frightening world dreamt up by the likes of J.K.Rowling, the happy schoolgirl is an inspiration to other sick children with her incredible outlook on life. I get on fine, chirps Eleanor, a big fan of the fantasy series. The only problem is when I accidentally bang into doors.  The brave schoolgirl, from Hampton, London, lost her sight in 2015 age four after being diagnosed with an inoperable cancerous brain tumour known as a Hypothalamic Low-Grade Glioma. Eleanor quickly underwent an 18-month regime of extensive chemotherapy, but sadly her eyesight was ravaged. Earlier this year, the Stollery family received a second blow when an MRI scan showed both a small growth of the large inoperable tumour, and a second, smaller tumour in a different location. The new lesion is currently growing at a rate of 1mm a month and the seven-year-old is now undergoing further chemotherapy.  But despite her disability and ongoing treatment, Eleanor is a normal little girl. I'm biased but she is infectious, dad Tim says. She is a little comedian and makes us laugh every day. We try to treat her as normally as possible - we don't put her on a pedestal because we don't want her to end up being an entitled child. She's wise beyond her years and such a positive spirit. She goes to a mainstream school and loves to listen to audio books. We think she maybe gets a little bit anxious when something new is about to begin but mainly, Eleanor just cracks on.  The lively seven-year-old is now officially registered as severely sight impaired (blind) as the cables that connect her eyes to the back of her brain are damaged beyond repair. Unless medical science catches up, she will never regain her eyesight. Dad Tim says: It is very difficult to explain what Eleanor can see. She sees light and dark, she sees huge objects but no detail, she sees changes in floor coverings if they go from light to dark or visa versa. But she can't really interpret colour or follow objects. Some days Eleanor seems to see better than others, but what she might see is so limited it is of no use to her in day to day life. She says she can see our pupils against the white eyeball but the rest of the face is dark. It sounds like something out of a horror film, like a Death Eater or a Dementor from Harry Potter. That's her reality and although we would be scared of it, she isn't.  As for Eleanor, she only encounters one obstacle at school. Eleanor says: People ask me how I do it but the only problem if someone leaves a cupboard door open and I bang into it. The cupboard doors at my school are white and whatever is behind it is white too so I can't see it's there at all. I can see very big shapes but not when they are the same colour next to each other and if I haven't seen it before then I don't know what it is. I can see the shapes on their [my parents'] faces and they have a line for their mouth and black dots for their eyes. If I get really close up I can just about tell the colour of their eyes. Most importantly, nothing stops Eleanor from having fun and feeding her curious mind. I can read braille and I love art and maths, she tells . Sometimes I get a bit of paper at home and make up equations. I solve them all myself. And my best friend at school is Romily because she's fun. When I say something really funny we both have a real laugh about it.  Eleanor's deep love of Harry Potter might be why she is unfazed by her dementor parents. I really love Harry Potter and my favourite character is Ron because he's so funny, she says. I've listened to both of the audio book collections [one is narrated by Stephen Fry and the other by Jim Dale] and watched all of films with audio description over and over. I also went to both parts of the Cursed Child with audio description at the theatre. It was amazing. When I was there, in the middle of it, I couldn't believe it was happening and it felt like it was going to go on forever but now it feels like it went really quick and at the end I wanted to do it all over again. Before the show started I got to do a touch tour where you feel some of the objects and the characters. It's really exciting. Hagrid held me up in the arena. Carefree and laughing, Eleanor jokes: I will like Harry Potter until I'm 500-years-old. I might have a portrait of Harry Potter put in my grave when I die. Eleanor is now undergoing a long journey of chemotherapy and other treatments for possibly well into her teenage years. Her type of tumour will never go away unless a cure is found. Along with Eleanor's mum Kelly Gurney and a huge team of supporters, Tim wants to raise awareness of the early symptoms of a brain tumour. If not for the family's persistence early on, Eleanor's could have been missed.

title: hes going blue dramatic 999
story: News"He's going blue!" Dramatic 999 call as frantic daughter talked through saving dad's life after heart stoppedGuest house owner Keith Richard collapsed at home after carrying suitcases upstairs after driving his family home from holiday&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom BevanKelly-Ann Mills12:37, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dramatic 999 call from two distraught daughters has been released revealing how they were talked saving their beloved dad's life after his lips began to turn blue. Guest house owner Keith Richards collapsed in his bedroom following a two month cruise around South America. The 64-year-old's heart stopped beating and he had a minimal chance of survival as his desperate family called an ambulance. He was kept alive when calm call handlers talked his panicking family how to give CPR before paramedics arrived and took over. Keith said he cannot remember driving his family home to Penzance, Cornwall, from Southampton on the day of the incident in March. He managed to carry some travel cases upstairs, before losing consciousness. He cut his head open in the resulting fall, which alerted his family to the emergency.  South Western Ambulance Service NHS Trust has now released a recording of the call with the daughter's frantic screams clearly audible in the background. Keith's daughter Louise tells the emergency medical dispatcher Hollie Eames: He's going blue. He has collapsed in the bedroom and he is not breathing. We don't know what's happened, he has cut his head open, there is blood everywhere. As she is calmly talked through how to give life-saving CPR with the help of her sister Lyndsey, she is also heard screaming: He is blue - he has stopped breathing - oh my God. Once ambulance crews arrived Keith was given seven shocks with a defibrillator, to get his heart beating again. He was then driven by ambulance to the Royal Cornwall Hospital and put into an induced coma. Against all the odds Keith has now made a full recovery and after three weeks of care he was back home and returned to work. At a special event at Penance Ambulance Station on Monday, Keith and his family were reunited with the medical team who rushed to his aid.  He said: “I am hugely thankful to everyone involved on that day for their prompt response, and more importantly their resolve in saving my life in a very frightening scenario. “I have no recollection of what happened. But I gather everyone got on board, and it was all hands on deck. My recovery was so quick. Three weeks after having a cardiac arrest, I was serving breakfast to guests. It was crazy. “I’ve had some down times since then, but I’m so grateful to still be here.” In a joint statement his daughters Lindsay and Louise said: “We would like to express our pure gratitude to everyone involved in saving our dad on that fateful day. “The lady who took our 999 call tried to keep us calm, which was nearly impossible, and the instructions she gave us contributed to saving his life. If the paramedics had not arrived so quickly or had not worked so tirelessly, our loved one would no longer be with us. “The work you all do deserves so much praise and admiration. What is more important and heroic than helping to save lives? We would all be lost without the services you provide. “You’ve given us the greatest gift, and we will always remember what you did. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.” The initial rescue team included Emergency Care Assistant (ECA) and student paramedic Grahame Barton, paramedic Jonathan Thomas, and student paramedic Bradley Gwennap-Bawden all arrived at the scene within five minutes.

title: hike number pupils expelled suspended
story: NewsHike in number of pupils expelled and suspended as school leaders suggest budgets and cuts are to blamePersistent disruptive behaviour remains the most common reason for exclusion, but there has also been a rise for other reasons including sexual misconduct, racial abuse, physical and verbal assault&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlison Kershaw13:35, 19 JUL 2018NewsGovernment figures show an increase in the number of school expulsions (file photo) (Image: The Image Bank)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email There has been a hike in permanent and fixed-period exclusions from schools in the space of a year, government statistics reveal.  More than 40 children a day are being expelled and at least 2,000 suspended from England's state schools, the figures suggest. Persistent disruptive behaviour remains the most common reason for exclusion, but there has also been a rise for other reasons including sexual misconduct, racial abuse, physical and verbal assault. The increase is likely to spark fresh debate about behaviour in schools. And school leaders suggested the increase was down to a squeeze on budgets and cuts to children's services.   The Department for Education (DfE) recently launched a review of exclusions in schools.  School standards minister Nick Gibb said schools should only use permanent exclusions as a last resort, but that the Government supports teachers who take proportionate steps to ensure good behaviour. The DfE figures show that schoolchildren were expelled on 7,720 occasions in 2016/17 - up from 6,685 in 2015/16. This is equivalent to 40.6 children a day.  Some 83% of permanent exclusions were in secondary schools. There were 381,865 fixed-period exclusions in England's state primary, secondary and special schools in 2016/17, up from 339,360. This is equivalent to around 2,010 a day.

story: NewsMassive 'Become a Pork Lover' bus sparks vegan protest as mounted police forced to interveneThe eye-catching pink bus was parked in Bristol's main shopping area to promote Spanish pork products - but vegan activists weren't happy&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie EvansKrishan Davis08:01, 19 JUL 2018Updated08:07, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A massive bus emblazoned with the words 'become a pork lover' has sparked a vegan protest - with mounted cops forced to intervene.  The pink vehicle, from the 'Pork Lovers Tour', has been parked in Bristol's main shopping area in a bid to promote Spanish pork products.  Featuring a giant heart-shaped snout and pigs' ears, it has led to an impromptu protest by vegan activists in Broadmead, Bristol Live reports.  Shoppers are being invited on board the bus to taste freebies, learn pork cooking techniques and receive nutrition advice.  Activities include workshops, cooking presentations and Spanish ham slicing demonstrations. However, the pro-pork vehicle drew the attention of the city's vegan community yesterday, with activists protesting against it. Onlookers described how there were angry exchanges between staff on the conspicuous 'Pork Lovers' bus and the protesters. They also said that Eat A Pitta employees from the nearby kiosk started handing out free falafel in support of the vegans. One of the protesters, named Jasmine, said of the pork promotional event: We are here because we are protesting this monstrosity.  It's basically propaganda telling people they can have pork imported from Spain for whatever reason that seems like a luxury, who knows. She went on to claim: Essentially we want to expose the truth in that welfare of pigs when they are kept on British farms is vile. They are not stunned or killed humanely, if that even exists, they are gassed and normally they are starved for 24 to 72 hours before they are killed. Mounted police officers had to intervene and calm both sides down. Jasmine continued: We are trying to expose there is no good that can come from this. Pork is a type one carcinogenic. There is no need for us to consume meat.

title: more 130 parents queue school
story: NewsMore than 130 parents queue at school gates from 3am to make sure kids get into breakfast clubThe breakfast club is a government scheme aimed at providing primary school children with the opportunity of receiving a free, healthy breakfast&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByWill Hayward11:56, 19 JUL 2018Updated13:12, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than 130 parents queued at the school gates from 3am to fight for a breakfast club spot for their children. The club at Ysgol Y Berllan Deg primary school in Llanedeyrn, Cardiff, has limited spaces for next year. Mums told Wales Online how important it was to them that their child was included with one saying I can’t risk not getting a place, I don’t have a plan B. The breakfast club is a government scheme aimed at providing young children with the opportunity of receiving a free, healthy breakfast at school each day. For many parents with a long commute it is vital as it allows them to drop their kids off early and get to work on time. The school opened its yearly applications for the next school year today and some parents were so worried about missing out they queued through the night outside the school gates. Have you had a similar experience? Email webnews@trinitymirror  At the front of the queue was Annett Farrow from Carmarthen, whose grandchild goes to the school. “We have been on the road since 1am and got here at 3am,” she said. “My son and daughter-in-law are on holiday so we had to come. If it gets them a place it will have been worth it. “We have bought biscuits and crisps - the only problem is the toilets. We have been using the toilets in the hotel opposite.”  For some parents like Leanne Taylor, who has been in her chair since 3.30am, there is no backup plan. She said: “I have two children, one of whom is starting in reception in September. “I had to do this last year when it did rain a bit. I had only moved into my house two days before and I didn’t have internet. I planned to bring my laptop and do some work while I waited. The police turned up and asked what I was doing.”  According to Leanne there is no other option for her if she wants to maintain her career. She said: “For some it is essential. I work opposite Tredegar House and I drive in. If I drop them off at 8.30 I won’t be getting into work until 10 because of the traffic. “If I didn’t have this I would not be able to go to work- I can’t risk not getting a place, I don’t have a plan B. “It is a really good school and I don’t think there is a fairer way to do it. “To do it you literally have to walk in and hand a form in. They then write what number you were in the queue on the form. “The ones that are here first are the ones that need it most. It gets longer and earlier because the people who did not get a place last year will get here earlier this year.” Another parent, who did not want to be named, said that in previous years it had been slightly different.  “It is a big talking point among parents,” she said. “You get a text two weeks before and then a letter. It goes straight in the diary. I have been doing this for two years and this is the biggest queue I have seen. “I don’t know how a single parent would be able to do it as they would have to bring their children with them. “In previous years people have bought multiple forms for friends and that has been banned because it wasn’t fair on the people who queued up. The atmosphere is much nicer this year.”

title: no wonder double glazing salesmen
story: NewsLying double glazing fraudster blew profits on designer clothes, private school fees and flights to Las VegasNo wonder the replacement window industry has such a bad reputation - court cases reveal range of lying, cheating, bullying sales tactics&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAndrew Penman07:16, 19 JUL 2018Updated11:58, 19 JUL 2018NewsBoxing fan Zulkernan Mahmood with Floyd Mayweather&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf there are many more cases like these then the double glazing industry will be in danger of getting a bad name. First up is Zulkernan Mahmood, who raked in &pound1.2million a year with his intimidating sales tactics. Despite boasting of a “seamless and problem-free installation every time” on his website, customers were left with shoddy doors and windows fitted by incompetent workers who sometimes left a trail of damage. Mahmood’s reps got customers to pay in full before installation by removing existing windows and demanding the balance “with the implication that the replacement windows would not be installed unless payment was made”, as trading standards officers put it. Other nasty tactics included: *Taking unauthorised payments from customers’ bank cards. When challenged the firm said this was to pay VAT – despite not being VAT registered. *Leaving jobs unfinished. *Ignoring complaints. *Failing to provide safety glass in locations where it was required by law. *Lying about belonging to an industry accreditation body.  Boxing fan Mahmood spent some of the money he made flying to Las Vegas to watch Floyd Mayweather, posting the pictures on Twitter, plus flights to Istanbul and Paris, private school fees and designer clothes. The 30-year-old from Bradford admitted fraud and consumer protection offences following a joint operation by police, trading standards and adult social care workers in West Yorkshire. He was given a suspended 15-month jail sentence and ordered to pay almost &pound65,000 in costs and compensation.  Mike Walsh, prosecuting on behalf of West Yorkshire Trading Standards, told Leeds crown court that damning evidence found during raids on his home and business included a text message in which the shyster wrote: “We’ve become a complete cowboy outlet”. After the trial Linda Davis, head of the West Yorkshire Financial Exploitation and Abuse Team, said: “This case highlights the unfair and fraudulent &shypractices that rogue traders will use against unsuspecting, often &shyvulnerable, consumers.”  Mahmood traded as UKHI Limited, UK Home Improvements and Energy Efficient Double Glazing and previously worked for double glazing giant Safestyle UK, which brings me to the second case. On Monday, in another prosecution brought by West Yorkshire trading standards, Safestyle was fined &pound120,000 in a trial that exposed a dreadful range of bullying, cheating ploys to get work.  In one of the most damning &shyjudgments I’ve heard in a consumer case, Judge Robert Moore told &shySheffield crown court that for two years the firm did not control its staff. “The offences were literally all over the country,” he said. “They frequently involved preying on the more vulnerable and often elderly. “There were lies and forceful calls deliberately wearing customers down. Faulty work was left &shyunrepaired and there was unpleasantness and perseverance.” In one case the rep challenged a reluctant customer to a fight.  In another, when a homeowner objected to an unsolicited visit and pointed to her “No cold-callers” door sticker, the rep said that this did not apply to him “as it didn’t say no cold-calling from Safestyle UK”. An 88-year-old woman was &shypressurised into giving her phone number by a rep who stood with “pen and paper repeating her dialling code”. And an 84-year-old man was told there would be “trouble” if he cancelled after phoning to complain about the cost. Safestyle UK, a trading name of HPAS Limited, admitted 13 unfair trading offences on day two of the trial. The court heard that it now has a new chief executive, Michael Gallacher, and a new chief financial officer. The judge said: “They have a lot to do.”

title: smart meter expert faces four
story: AdvertorialSmart meter expert faces four sceptics in remarkable Q&A - sparking shock u-turnOur SMOPs quizzed Energy UK expert over security, bills and both home and data safety&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Masters15:24, 19 JUL 2018AdvertorialVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet Money Deals updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe are acutely aware there are still potential customers out there who have some genuine concerns about the new technically savvy smart meters that the Government has asked all energy suppliers to offer every household by the end of 2020. So we searched the country and found four SMOPs (Smart Meter Opponents) who revealed their worries to us. We heard the same issues over and over again. Security, inaccurate bills and both home and data safety were all common themes. In a bid to alleviate their concerns and iron out any undue fears, we invited our SMOPs to a round-the-table discussion with an expert equiped to answer their questions.  Audrey Gallacher, from industry body Energy UK, was on hand to chat about topics that were most prevalent on our SMOPs’ minds and to explain the positive impact smart meters can have on their lives, the future and how they could fundamentally save them money. But our SMOPs were armed with tough questions and pushed our expert hard, determined to discover if smart meters really are the way forward. So what did they ask?  Paul, 61, a sales manager from Manchester, said: “I’ve been very concerned about smart meter security and openly sceptical about the real cost saving benefits for a long time.” His feelings were echoed by foster mum Sarah, 50, from Herts. “I’ve always thought they would be more of a hindrance than a help,” she said. But as the conversation evolved and Audrey, Director of Retail Energy Supply, addressed each of our SMOP’s very genuine worries, it soon became evident that despite their initial fears they gradually began to understand how smart meters really could have a positive benefit on their everyday lives.  Paula, 50, who lives with her partner, Ian, 48, and is carer to her elderly and poorly mum Doreen, 80, said: “I really wasn’t sure what to expect but it was encouraging to see Audrey was very receptive to our fairly tough questions.” The mum of one, who lives in a remote area and often has her four-year-old granddaughter Scarlett, to stay was at first anxious about having unknown fitters come into her home. She said: “I was worried about leaving myself and my family in a very vulnerable situation.” Expert confirmed engineers are heavily vetted    Audrey reassured our SMOPs that all engineers are heavily vetted and follow rigorous regulations and guidelines to ensure customers’ safety remains the highest priority. Paula said: “I felt so much better being reassured from someone who works so closely with Smart Energy GB that no fitter would be able to walk in before being fully trained to an extremely high level.” Another common concern was that the initial installation of a modern smart meter would be invasive and time-consuming. Sarah, a busy volunteer, said: “I’d assumed it was a full day’s job and my carpets and floorboards would need lifting that would cause mess and disruption.” She was pleasantly surprised to discover the process only takes approximately two hours and that the smart meters are usually positioned in the same spot as your old meter. Stay-at- home dad, Edward, 27,from South Wales, was still sceptical as to how he could really save money. Smart meter safety code in place    Audrey explained how the data provided on the in-home display indicates when customers are using more than average amounts of energy, allowing them to make changes and assess whether they needed to be using all the appliances causing a surge. She revealed how smart meter customers will be offered competitive tariffs and be able to swap suppliers with ease. Audrey said there is a safety mechanism in place for customers whose energy usage revealed an inexplicable change. The data can indicate to energy suppliers any potential issues, who can then make every effort to fix the problem. Paul, 61, said: “This isn’t something I had even considered and is a real positive for elderly or more impaired customers who maybe hadn’t realised there was a problem. “It’s reassuring to know the energy companies will be watching out for any potential issues.” The conclusion

title: thrifty bride groom use food
story: NewsThrifty bride and groom use food destined for BIN to feed 140 wedding guests - who have no ideaCherie Harris and James Mainwaring created a mouth-watering menu for guests at their wedding reception last Saturday - and it cost just £6 a head&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie EvansSamantha yule12:27, 19 JUL 2018Updated12:30, 19 JUL 2018NewsNewlyweds Cherie and James are pictured with their baby daughter, Iona (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA thrifty bride and groom used food destined for landfill to serve beautiful meals to their 140 wedding guests - who had no idea. Cherie Harris and James Mainwaring enlisted the help of a food waste charity to create a delicious menu for their reception last Saturday. The menu was made up entirely of food heading for the bin. The green-minded couple, aided by The Real Junk Food Project, wanted their wedding to have as little mark on the environment as possible. They did this by leaving no food waste - and also saved money in the process, with the cost for the food thought to be just &pound6 a head. Cherie and James initially didn't tell their guests who provided the catering for their reception at a village hall in Leeds, West Yorkshire.  The bride, 36, said: We wanted the food to speak for itself. We did not tell our guests what they were eating until the speeches. They were very surprised but also very impressed. The food was absolutely beautiful and really made our day. We could not have asked for anything better. In fact, the beauty of a spread delivered by the RJFP is that the customer never really knows what they are going to get. It is all down to the luck of what comes into the warehouse. At the weekend, Cherie and James's guests were treated to a sit-down hot buffet which was fit for kings at East Keswick Village Hall. They had spinach and chickpea curry, chicken and bacon pies, sausage and bean cassoulet, ratatouille and cold meats and pickles.  Other dishes included a cheese board, oven roasted thyme and lemon chicken and tortilla cups filled with Mexican salad (gallo d'pico) - all created from scratch by the RJFP team. These were accompanied by a selection of tasty salads, pasta dishes and veggies - with veggie cakes and a Greggs donut tower for dessert. RJFP food is collected from supermarkets, sandwich chains and fast food outlets, using items they would have to throw out because of their own health and safety regulations. All of this food is still perfectly fine for human consumption, and no laws are being broken by feeding guests with it. The charity uses the food to cater nationally for events, feed customers in pay-as-you-feel cafes and stock pay-as-you-feel supermarkets. It also uses it to supply food for schools. Emma Buckle, Events Co-ordinator of RJFP Leeds, said the organisation would be aware that it has a wedding on its books, so would do its best to freeze any food it wishes to put away for the wedding.  Other than that, it relies a lot on praying to the food fairies for certain ingredients to come in - and it usually does, she added. The menu the charity creates for the special day is made up entirely from junk food, with not a single ingredient ever purchased. Cherie worked as a carer until she went on maternity leave after the birth of her and James's baby daughter, Iona,15 weeks ago. She had booked the catering for their wedding a year ago. She and saxophonist James, 29, who plays for the popular band Roller Trio, had a menu featuring a mix of veggie, vegan and meat feasts. The mum-of-one, from Leeds, said: When we looked at other food options you can find that menus are rather limited, with the RJFP the possibilities are endless. You get a range of food that is beautiful, original and delicious. The couple's guests were spoiled with meals concocted by brilliant chefs used to thinking on their feet to prepare delicious food from waste.  Our working conditions are like an episode of Ready Steady Cook, Emma said. And using food destined for landfill is relatively cheap. Of course, there still has to be payment for the food preparation, as well as staffing and collection costs. But because the food has come free, the costs are low. Prices start from a cold buffet costing as little as &pound5 a head, with a hot one costing &pound6 a head. Emma said: This is food that really does not cost the earth. It is not only plastic waste that is bad for the environment. Even food, when it breaks down, emits greenhouse gasses, including carbon dioxide and methane. Saturday's buffet, going on 250g per person, saved 35 kilos of waste.

title: uk weather britain set scorching
story: NewsUK Weather: Britain set for scorching weekend with temperatures set to hit 30CThe latest hot spell comes after the Met Office said Britain could see a record-breaking summer if temperatures stay above average&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHenry VaughanDanya BazaraaNews Reporter12:18, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain is set for another scorching weekend with temperatures set to hit 30C as the heat continues to rise. The latest hot spell comes after the Met Office said the UK could see a record-breaking summer if temperatures stay above average.  With the start of the school holidays , it is time to bring out the barbecues again.  But although much of the country will stay dry today, some much needed rain is expected to reach Scotland by the afternoon and possible showers could hit in eastern England. The rain will move south into northern England, Wales and the Midlands overnight and hot conditions in the South East could even trigger thunderstorms tomorrow afternoon. A Met Office yellow weather warning is in place for the region between 2pm and 11.59pm.  Met Office meteorologist Dean Hall said: The last heatwave ended with a temperature breakdown, but it looks as though we are going back into the heat again. The heat will be building into the weekend and early next week. But with the increasing heat and humidity there's always a chance of one or two thunderstorms. Mr Hall said most of the country would enjoy warm and dry conditions with the hot, sunny weather predicted to last into next week when top temperatures could reach 31C.  It's a very warm weekend with plenty of fine, dry weather around, with the exception being a little bit of cloud in western Scotland and Northern Ireland. he continued. But otherwise a good deal of fine, dry weather and very warm if not hot conditions. Conditions have been unusually dry, with the UK having just 47mm of rain so far, making it the driest start to summer in modern records which date back to 1961.  The Met Office says this summer is set to beat 1976 to be the hottest summer since records began 108 years ago in 1910.   It said: “Temperatures this summer are remarkable. If the rest of the summer is average, 2018 will certainly rank in the top 10 warmest summers on record - and if we continue to see above-average temperatures, it could well be record breaking. “June 1 to July 16 had an average daily maximum temperature across the country of 20.9C. The average daily maximum in the hottest summer on record, 1976, was 21C. “And if the rest of the summer was average, we would also be in the top five sunniest summers on record, and in the top 10 driest summers of all time.”

title: young waitress tackles customer who
story: NewsYoung waitress tackles customer who groped her bum in pizza restaurant - before police arrest him for assaultEmelia Holden, 21, was not going to let the man get away with his actions at Vinne Van GoGo's pizza restaurant in downtown Savannah, Georgia - and says "he got what he deserves"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPesala BandaraAmber Hicks15:19, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 21-year-old waitress at a pizza restaurant gave a customer the shock of his life when she slammed him to the ground after he grabbed her bum. Emelia Holden was sorting out menus when the man walked behind her and brazenly squeezed her rear. Livid by what had happened, Emelia sprung into action, grabbed the man by the neck of his T-shirt and slammed him on a nearby chair before giving him a piece of her mind. Quick-thinking Emelia said: I just did what I felt was best. I took the guy down and had my co-workers call the police. As soon as the cops saw the CCTV footage, they immediately arrested the man. He sat in jail until Monday so in my opinion, he got what he deserved.  All that I want from my experiences is for women to know that it's okay to stand up for yourself. She added: You have every right to wear what you want and you most certainly have every right to defend yourself. The incident, which happened in a matter of seconds, was caught on CCTV. Police were called to the scene and a man was immediately arrested after cops were shown the footage. The incident took place at Vinne Van GoGo's pizza restaurant in downtown Savannah, Georgia, just before 11pm on Saturday, June 30.  The man was released on Monday, July 2. The CCTV video begins by showing waitress Emelia taking another table's order in the patio area of the restaurant. She finishes taking the table's orders and takes their menus back to the restaurant counter. As she does this, the male customer begins walking towards her. While Emelia sorts out the restaurant menus and order pads, the man reaches his left arm out and grabs her bottom. He then walks away but Emelia immediately chases after him. She grabs him by the back of his red t-shirt and puts him in a headlock- before pushing the man down to the ground.

title: airbus beluga xl airbus flight
story: News'Whale in the sky' makes maiden voyage as Airbus Beluga XL departs Toulouse sending smiling giant soaring through airThe impressive aircraft, designed to resemble a Beluga whale, took to the skies as part of a 10-month test to see if the jet will be worthy of entering service&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary10:41, 19 JUL 2018Updated13:11, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA plane branded a 'whale in the sky' has made its maiden voyage as the Airbus Beluga XL departed Toulouse this morning. The impressive aircraft, designed to resemble a Beluga whale, took to the skies as part of a 10-month test to see if the jet will be worthy of entering service. Airbus plan to eventually bring the air cargo craft to Broughton in North Wales. Complete with a whale mouth and eyes on each side of the nose, the Beluga XL will replace the current five plane Beluga ST fleet . The new jet can carry six more tonnes and is 20ft longer, while being powered by two Rolls-Royce Trent 700 high bypass turbofan aircraft engines. It also has an enlarged fuselage “bubble” section that is six metres longer and one metre wider than on the Beluga ST.  The maiden flight is expected to take around three and a half hours before landing back at Toulouse. Tim Orr, head of branding at Airbus, said: The six designs we proposed for consideration by employees respected our brand identity while running from the conventional to the unconventional, even adding a touch of fun. Airbus were live tweeting the plane's maiden voyage this morning, jokingly posting: Whale, whale, whale...that's a lovely day for a maiden flight don't you think. They later tweeted whale done after a successful take off.

title: emmanuel macrons deputy chief staff
story: NewsEmmanuel Macron's deputy chief of staff dresses up as riot cop to attack anti-Government protestersAstonishing video shot in Paris shows the French President's security advisor Alexandra Benalla attacking a young man he slaps round the head and woman who he grabs by the neck&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPeter AllenStephen JonesDeputy News Editor09:55, 19 JUL 2018Updated09:58, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA senior member of Emmanuel Macron's staff has been caught out impersonating a riot cop in order to beat up anti-government protesters. Astonishing video shot during a street demonstration in Paris shows security advisor Alexandra Benalla attacking a young man he slaps round the head and woman who he grabs by the neck. The fallout which has emerged since the video became public has led to a political scandal - with opponents of French president accusing him of trying to cover up the attacks. There are now calls for deputy chief of staff Benalla, who is in his mid-30s, to be imprisoned after what happened at the demonstration on May 1 – the country's traditional day of street action. The event this year saw hundreds of thousands campaigning across France against Mr Macron’s employment reforms - and it's now transpired Benalla was in the thick of it.  The video footage shows deputy chief of staff at the Elysee Palace had donned a police helmet, despite not being authorised to do so. He can clearly be seen first of all grabbing a young woman by the neck. Benalla then turns his attention to a bearded Left-wing activist who has been apprehended by gendarmes. Then burly Benalla pulls the man away from the police, and starts slapping him around the head. When other demonstrators start shouting at Benalla, he looks scared of being identified behind his visor, before slinking off to a caf&eacute.  Alexis Corbiere, an MP and spokesman for former far-Left presidential candidate Jean-Luc Melenchon, said he ‘asked for penal sanctions’ against a ‘colleague of Macron who disguised himself as a police officer to commit violence.’ And Paris barrister Raquel Garrido said: ‘I hope that prosecutors have already initiated criminal proceedings against Alexandre Benalla, head of security of Emmanuel Macron. In addition to violence, it is question of usurpation..’ According to Le Monde, which broke the story in France, there are other incriminating videos to go with the ones already posted on platforms including Twitter.  Benalla refused to comment, but Mr Macron’s chief of staff said: ‘Alexandre Benalla had warned me two days earlier [before the demonstration] that he wanted to take part in an operation with the police to see how a large demonstration was handled. ‘He asked me for permission, I gave it to him, but making it clear that he was an observer. ‘The day after the demonstration, I was informed by a colleague that Mr Benalla had been recognised in the field as being involved in law enforcement operations, and I saw the videos. ‘I summoned the same day, I asked him if it was him.’ When Benalla said yes, Mr Macron himself called for Benalla to be suspended from his duties for 15 days up until May 19, but the incident was otherwise hushed up.

title: pouting model branded sick after
story: NewsPouting model branded 'sick' after taking selfie with dead father laying in hospital bedJelica Ljubicic, who describes herself as a singer and model, posed for the camera while her father could be seen laying behind her&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAngjela Trajkovska12:01, 19 JUL 2018Updated12:30, 19 JUL 2018NewsJelica pouts as she turns her head towards her father laying in the hospital bed (Image: CEN)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pouting model has been branded 'sick' after taking a selfie with her dead father laying in a hospital bed. Jelica Ljubicic, who describes herself as a singer and model, posed for the camera while her father could be seen laying behind her. His head had fallen to one side, with local media in Serbia reporting the man had died shortly before the image was taken. The bizarre image was posted on social media before Jelica received huge backlash from viewers who were baffled by the upload. Along with the image, she wrote a heartfelt message to her father.  Blonde-haired Jelica said: Dad...rest in peace. We have fought as much as we can, but it is not our will. We don't decide how long we will live. He left us in the 67th year of life. Thank you for everything, I am grateful for being your daughter and having you as my father. Thank you for bringing us to the right path. Rest in peace, you will always stay in our hearts.
